pages.text: $(item)Printed Circuit Boards/$ (PCB's) are important components used in many higher tier machines and tools. Making a $(item)PCB/$   requires a few steps.$(p)First of all, make an $(item)Empty PCB/$ in the $(l:manufacturing/pressure_chamber)Pressure Chamber/$ as shown opposite. There are then two methods to proceed (see overleaf).

pages.title: Method #1
pages.text: This method is the only one available initially, and is somewhat slow: you can develop a $(item)PCB/$ chemically by putting it in a $(l:manufacturing/uv_light_box)UV Light Box/$ and then throwing the exposed $(item)Empty PCB/$ in a pool of $(l:manufacturing/etching_acid)Etching Acid/$ to turn it into an $(item)Unassembled PCB/$.

pages.title: Recycling Failed PCB's
pages.text: The etching process has a chance of failure if the $(item)Empty PCB/$ was not 100% exposed in the $(l:manufacturing/uv_light_box)UV Light Box/$; you can recycle $(item)Failed PCB's/$ in a $(item)Furnace/$ (or other smelting device)

pages.title: Method #2
pages.text: Once you can make an $(l:manufacturing/assembly_system)Assembly System/$, you can use that to turn $(item)Empty PCB's/$ directly into an $(item)Unassembled PCB/$ with an $(item)Assembly Program: Laser/$.$(p)There's no need to expose it in a $(item)UV Light Box/$ or drop it in $(item)Etching Acid/$ in this case.
Finally, you can add some $(l:components/capacitor)Capacitors/$ and $(l:components/transistor)Transistors/$ to assemble the finished $(item)Printed Circuit Board/$!
